Dear Ms. Thomas-Cloud:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on February
28, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person has
not been named in a central registry case as the perpetrator of
child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in any state where the
person lived in the 5 years preceding hire.
One of nine personnel files reviewed did not contain documentation that central
registry clearance was completed prior to employment as required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation
(3) An agency shall complete a special evaluation within 45
calendar days after receipt of the information. The total time for
the completion of the investigation shall not exceed 90 calendar
days without written approval from the chief administrator or his
or her designee.
One of one special investigations reviewed that exceeded 90 calendar days lacked
documentation of director approval.
R 400.12421 Visitation and parenting time
An agency shall have a policy regarding visitation and parenting
time that contains, at a minimum, all of the following:
(b) An agency social service worker shall visit the foster child
and the foster parent in the foster parent’s home at least once
every month.
One of three open independent living files reviewed did not have monthly visitation
with the worker and child in the placement as required.
File one: There is no documented home visit with the child in the placement for the
month of December 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/18/2020 RENEWAL, 2/1/2021 CAP approved

(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care or child
abuse/neglect during this licensing period. There were two incidents of
substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing period.
A special evaluation initiated on 4/7/2021 determined the foster parents slapped a
foster child as a disciplinary measure in response to behavioral issues while on a
family trip. The family was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency
policy. A Corrective Action Plan was implemented, and the family is now back in
compliance. The agency’s investigation of this matter and the approved CAP were
reviewed and found to be appropriate.
A special evaluation initiated on 10/20/2020 determined the foster parents locked a
foster child out of the house, a child was not provided medication properly, the
kitchen is locked at a certain time and food is restricted, and the most utilized
discipline in the home is writing sentences to an extensive amount, which is an issue
that was previously addressed. The Corrective Action Plan was implemented, and
the family was placed on First Provisional License. The agency’s investigation of this
matter and the approved CAP were reviewed and found to be appropriate.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
SIR 2021C0214006 was initiated on 2/12/2021 due to allegations the agency is not
considering relative placement options prior to placing in a licensed, nonrelative
home and the agency is not conducting placement change FTM’s. The investigation
determined violations of FOM 722-0B Family Team Meeting. A CAP was approved
and continues to be implemented at this time.
The renewal inspection completed on 12/18/2020 with a corrective action plan
approved on 2/1/2021. During the review the agency had ten violations. Four
citations were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this period
under review the agency expressed the impact that the COVID-19 pandemic had on
overall compliance. In addition, the agency noted that staff turnover and retention
impacted overall compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment reported the agency’s difficulty in meeting some
of the requirements due to COVID 19. Specifically, the assessment mentioned
contract amendment requirements that were not accurately reflected in Book of
9

Business and MMR data, such as video conferencing. In addition, the agency
experienced staff turnover and difficulty hiring new staff due to a limited number of
qualified applicants. It was noted that staff turnover had been reduced from the
previous year.
The Chief Administrator Assessment indicated the agency adopted Clinical Case
Reviews in response to the previous year’s audit. The agency began utilizing LEAN
methods toward the end of 2021 to retain staff and address compliance with policy,
ISEP and audit compliance. The agency has also implemented mandatory protected
time as well as training centered around planning and organization. The CA
expressed confidence that these changes will positively impact several areas of
compliance over the next review period.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with six staff via telephone. Staff acknowledged some
challenges during the last review period regarding COVID 19 as well as difficult
clients and the loss of face-to-face contact due to working remote. However, the staff
reported those challenges were outside of agency control and felt the agency
adapted well. Staff reported feeling supported by supervision and noted supervisors
and co-workers are available to assist as needed. Staff also expressed the agency
has effective systems in place to ensure compliance.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
